Cliveâ€™s Album of the Year 2015

  • Clive Murray

    Rock guitarist and gentleman adventurer from a land before time.

Clive Murray

5 January 2017 â€¢ 4 min read

In 2015 I left my two-year contract in Westminster to go work for a Jimmy Wales venture, and the nearly 2-year wait for my BlacKat DC7 finally came to an end. It was both the International Year of Light, and of Soils. Something for everyone there, then.

The Charlie Hebdo shooting happened, an earthquake hit Nepal killing over 9000 people, Sepp Blatter, Greek money bother, NASA did a flyby of Pluto and found liquid water on Mars, Volkswagen were caught rigging emissions tests, a stampede at Mecca killed over 2200 people, Elon Muskâ€™s SpaceX launched and landed a reusable rocket, and there was further general increasing unpleasantness in the Middle East.

Off to Valhalla (or their designated equivalent) went (as always, etc.) Leonard Nimoy, Terry Pratchett, Ben E. King, Ruth Rendell, B. B. King, Christopher Lee, Mr. Steed (Patrick Macnee), Omar Sharif, Cilla Black, Batgirl (Yvonne Craig), Wes Craven, Jackie Collins, Phil Taylor, Jonah Lomu, Scott Weiland, Jimmy Hill and of course Lemmy.

Honourable mentions

Furyon - Lost Salvation

Brighton metallers Furyonâ€™s second album is as good as the first, sprinkled liberally as it is with Chris Greenâ€™s crackling guitar work. Shame he left the band after this album, as heâ€™s going to be tough to replace. Top track: â€œLost Salvationâ€

Lonely Robot - Please Come Home

The long-awaited solo album project from British prog mastermind John Mitchell (It Bites, Arena, Kino, Frost*) is nothing short of genius. My band happened to be at Johnâ€™s studio recording our EP while John was working on this and we got to hear some of it before it was released. Itâ€™s absolutely top-drawer stuff, and Iâ€™m eagerly awaiting the follow-up. Câ€™mon John, whatâ€™s the hold-up? You busy or something? Top track: â€œGod vs. Manâ€

Mumford & Sons - Wilder Mind

Yeah yeah. Weâ€™ve done that before, Iâ€™m sure. I like the Mumfords and you can stuff it. On this, their third album, theyâ€™ve dropped the banjo-and-waistcoat trappings and just written some songs. I like them. You might too, if you give them a try. Top track: â€œBelieveâ€

Plini - The End of Everything

Aussie wunderkind Plini goes from strength to strength, and in 2015 he completed his trilogy of EPs, the previous two being Sweet Nothings and Other things. Sounds like just the thing. This guy deserves every ounce of the recognition heâ€™s getting in guitar spheres right now, and I hope to catch him live one day. This is his best stuff yet. Top track: â€œPaper Moonâ€

Teramaze - Her Halo

Nope, I hadnâ€™t either. I completely forget how I happened across this prog-metal outfit from Down Under, but happen I did, and this is some great stuff. Sort of reminiscent of early Dream Theater without half the pretension. Great singer too. Top track: â€œFor the Innocentâ€

And the winner isâ€¦

Coheed and Cambria - The Color Before the Sun

Well, now. What can I say about C&C that hasnâ€™t been said copiously elsewhere? If you like prog, or even just interesting rock music, youâ€™ve probably heard of them. If youâ€™re anything like me (and I know I am*) youâ€™ve probably got every one of their CDs and donâ€™t plan on stopping any time soon.

Unusually, this is their eighth full length album, yet their first non-concept album. Again, if you know anything about them youâ€™ll know that their previous output is effectively the soundtrack to The Amory Wars, a series of sci-fi comics and graphic novels written by the bandâ€™s frontman Claudio Sanchez, and is extraordinarily good taken with or without that alongside.

So can they do it when they donâ€™t have a plot to follow? Of course they can. This is some of their catchiest work too, and thatâ€™s saying something. Sanchez canâ€™t half write a melody and a hook. So if you thought they sounded interesting before, but didnâ€™t want to buy into that concept nonsense, get this. In fact, just get it generally. Itâ€™s brilliant.

* Ta, iffy50.

Top tracks: â€œIslandâ€, â€œFrom Here to Marsâ€, â€œYou Got Spirit, Kidâ€

No Turkey of the Year for 2015, as there just wasnâ€™t anything in my collection from the year that I found disappointing. Perhaps I bought less music, or perhaps I just got a bit more discerning about what I shelled out for. (Yes kids, music costs money, and so it should.)

One side note though: I had Museâ€™s Drones listed as a possible honourable mention contender. I mentioned this to a friend, who said that they make him physically sick. I said yeah, Matt Bellamyâ€™s constant hectoring to WAKE UP SHEEPLE can get a bit tiresome after a while, and he made his feelings very clear. Quoth he: â€œF*** off you middle class post alt rock prickâ€.
